Urbana, Illinois
Dear Harold:
i
Sorry to have delayed answering your December 16 letter.
There were a few things I needed to talk to John about
before laying out the program. I certainly agree with you and
Harry; the only way to get anything started is to buckle
down and do it. I do think that the project should be
developed in several phases. The enclosed proposal shows
how these phases might line up.
I think it is optimistic to expect much in the way of actual
exchangeable material out of the first phase. The big
hold up will be in finding stations with facilities, money,
and people to invest in the project. However, the Ford
consultation money can be spent advantageously to take care
of getting it into a starting position. I feel there is
a great potential for these Utilization Kits but they are
not lying around ready to be picked up. From our preliminary
committee meetings, it was evident that everyone needed
the material and knew the kind of thing that was needed,
but had no source.
If there were some place (and as of now I know of none) willing
to invest money in the production of these kits, or if there
were some producing money available, then I could see how
we might get at least one Kit in the works•
Incidentally, we have submitted a Project Proposal on utili¬
zation to the Title VII Office. If it is approved, we will
have a film report on utilization available. We suggested
in the Proposal that this be distributed through NAEB channels.
We commented that this might become a part of the Utilization
Kits file. Perhaps, some similar material can be obtained
